template.name: Linux by SNMP
template.description:
Template OS Linux
MIBs used: EtherLike-MIB HOST-RESOURCES-MIB SNMPv2-MIB UCD-DISKIO-MIB UCD-SNMP-MIB IF-MIB
You can discuss this template or leave feedback on our forum https://www.zabbix.com/forum/zabbix-suggestions-and-feedback/387225-discussion-thread-for-official-zabbix-template-for-linux
Template tooling version used: 0.41

trigger.name: Unavailable by ICMP ping
trigger.description: Last three attempts returned timeout. Please check device connectivity.

trigger.expression: min(/Linux by SNMP/icmppingloss,5m)>{$ICMP_LOSS_WARN} and min(/Linux by SNMP/icmppingloss,5m)<100
trigger.name: High ICMP ping loss

dependency.name: High ICMP ping loss
dependency.expression: min(/Linux by SNMP/icmppingloss,5m)>{$ICMP_LOSS_WARN} and min(/Linux by SNMP/icmppingloss,5m)<100

item.name: SNMP traps (fallback)
item.description: The item is used to collect all SNMP traps unmatched by other snmptrap items

item.name: System contact details
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The textual identification of the contact person for this managed node, together with information on how to contact this person. If no contact information is known, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: Load average (1m avg)
item.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB

item.name: Load average (5m avg)
item.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB

item.name: Load average (15m avg)
item.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB

item.name: Number of CPUs
item.description: MIB: HOST-RESOURCES-MIB Count the number of CPU cores by counting number of cores discovered in hrProcessorTable using LLD

parameters.parameter: //count the number of cores return JSON.parse(value).length;

item.name: System description
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB A textual description of the entity. This value should include the full name and version identification of the system's hardware type, software operating-system, and networking software.

item.name: Uptime (hardware)
item.description: MIB: HOST-RESOURCES-MIB The amount of time since this host was last initialized. Note that this is different from sysUpTime in the SNMPv2-MIB [RFC1907] because sysUpTime is the uptime of the network management portion of the system.

item.name: System location
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The physical location of this node (e.g., `telephone closet, 3rd floor'). If the location is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: System name
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB An administratively-assigned name for this managed node.By convention, this is the node's fully-qualified domain name. If the name is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

trigger.expression: last(/Linux by SNMP/system.name,#1)<>last(/Linux by SNMP/system.name,#2) and length(last(/Linux by SNMP/system.name))>0
trigger.name: System name has changed
trigger.description: System name has changed. Ack to close.

item.name: Uptime (network)
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The time (in hundredths of a second) since the network management portion of the system was last re-initialized.

item.name: System object ID
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The vendor's authoritative identification of the network management subsystem contained in the entity. This value is allocated within the SMI enterprises subtree (1.3.6.1.4.1) and provides an easy and unambiguous means for determining`what kind of box' is being managed. For example, if vendor`Flintstones, Inc.' was assigned the subtree1.3.6.1.4.1.4242, it could assign the identifier 1.3.6.1.4.1.4242.1.1 to its `Fred Router'.

item.name: Free swap space
item.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB The amount of swap space currently unused or available.

item.name: Free swap space in %
item.description: The free space of swap volume/file in percent.

item.name: Total swap space
item.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB The total amount of swap space configured for this host.

item.name: Available memory
item.description: Please note that memory utilization is a rough estimate, since memory available is calculated as free+buffers+cached, which is not 100% accurate, but the best we can get using SNMP.

item.name: Memory (buffers)
item.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB Memory used by kernel buffers (Buffers in /proc/meminfo).

item.name: Memory (cached)
item.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB Memory used by the page cache and slabs (Cached and Slab in /proc/meminfo).

item.name: Free memory
item.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB

item.name: Total memory
item.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB Total memory in Bytes.

item.name: Memory utilization
item.description: Please note that memory utilization is a rough estimate, since memory available is calculated as free+buffers+cached, which is not 100% accurate, but the best we can get using SNMP.

trigger.name: High memory utilization
trigger.description: The system is running out of free memory.

dependency.name: Lack of available memory
dependency.expression: max(/Linux by SNMP/vm.memory.available[snmp],5m)<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} and last(/Linux by SNMP/vm.memory.total[memTotalReal.0])>0

item.name: SNMP agent availability
item.description: Availability of SNMP checks on the host. The value of this item corresponds to availability icons in the host list. Possible value: 0 - not available 1 - available 2 - unknown

trigger.name: No SNMP data collection
trigger.description: SNMP is not available for polling. Please check device connectivity and SNMP settings.

discovery_rule.name: CPU discovery
discovery_rule.description: This discovery will create set of per core CPU metrics from UCD-SNMP-MIB, using {#CPU.COUNT} in preprocessing. That's the only reason why LLD is used.

item_prototype.name: CPU guest time
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB Guest time (time spent running a virtual CPU for a guest operating system).

parameters.parameter: //to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores. return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototype.name: CPU guest nice time
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB Time spent running a niced guest (virtual CPU for guest operating systems under the control of the Linux kernel).

parameters.parameter: //to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores. return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototype.name: CPU idle time
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB The time the CPU has spent doing nothing.

parameters.parameter: //to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores. return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototype.name: CPU interrupt time
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB The amount of time the CPU has been servicing hardware interrupts.

parameters.parameter: //to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores. return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototype.name: CPU iowait time
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB Amount of time the CPU has been waiting for I/O to complete.

parameters.parameter: //to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores. return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototype.name: CPU nice time
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that have been niced.

parameters.parameter: //to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores. return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototype.name: CPU softirq time
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB The amount of time the CPU has been servicing software interrupts.

parameters.parameter: //to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores. return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototype.name: CPU steal time
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB The amount of CPU 'stolen' from this virtual machine by the hypervisor for other tasks (such as running another virtual machine).

parameters.parameter: //to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores. return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototype.name: CPU system time
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB The time the CPU has spent running the kernel and its processes.

parameters.parameter: //to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores. return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototype.name: CPU user time
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that are not niced.

parameters.parameter: //to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores. return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototype.name: CPU utilization
item_prototype.description: CPU utilization in %.

parameters.parameter: //Calculate utilization return (100 - value)

trigger_prototype.name: High CPU utilization
trigger_prototype.description: CPU utilization is too high. The system might be slow to respond.

parameters.parameter: //count the number of CPU cores return JSON.stringify([{"{#CPU.COUNT}": value, "{#SNMPINDEX}": 0, "{#SINGLETON}":""}])

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits received
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The total number of octets received on the interface, including framing characters. This object is a 64-bit version of ifInOctets. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits sent
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters. This object is a 64-bit version of ifOutOctets.Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Speed
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB An estimate of the interface's current bandwidth in units of 1,000,000 bits per second. If this object reports a value of `n' then the speed of the interface is somewhere in the range of `n-500,000' to`n+499,999'. For interfaces which do not vary in bandwidth or for those where no accurate estimation can be made, this object should contain the nominal bandwidth. For a sub-layer which has no concept of bandwidth, this object should be zero.

parameters.parameter: 1h

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Operational status
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The current operational state of the interface. - The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packet scan be passed - If ifAdminStatus is down(2) then ifOperStatus should be down(2) - If ifAdminStatus is changed to up(1) then ifOperStatus should change to up(1) if the interface is ready to transmit and receive network traffic - It should change todormant(5) if the interface is waiting for external actions (such as a serial line waiting for an incoming connection) - It should remain in the down(2) state if and only if there is a fault that prevents it from going to the up(1) state - It should remain in the notPresent(6) state if the interface has missing(typically, hardware) components.

trigger_prototype.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
trigger_prototype.description:
This trigger expression works as follows: 1. Can be triggered if operations status is down. 2. {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 - user can redefine Context macro to value - 0. That marks this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down. 3. {TEMPLATE_NAME:METRIC.diff()}=1) - trigger fires only if operational status was up(1) sometime before. (So, do not fire 'ethernal off' interfaces.)
WARNING: if closed manually - won't fire again on next poll, because of .diff.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Interface type
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The type of interface. Additional values for ifType are assigned by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA), through updating the syntax of the IANAifType textual convention.

parameters.parameter: 1d

trigger_prototype.expression: change(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])<0 and last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])>0 and ( last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=6 or last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=7 or last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=11 or last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=62 or last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=69 or last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=117 ) and (last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])<>2)
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: (change(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])>0 and last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2)>0) or (last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2)
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototype.description: This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Ack to close.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))

trigger_prototype.expression: (avg(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.in[ifHCInOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}]) or avg(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.out[ifHCOutOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])) and last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])>0
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: avg(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.in[ifHCInOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}]) and avg(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.out[ifHCOutOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High bandwidth usage
trigger_prototype.description: The network interface utilization is close to its estimated maximum bandwidth.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Linux by SNMP/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))

discovery_rule.name: EtherLike-MIB Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovering interfaces from IF-MIB and EtherLike-MIB. Interfaces with up(1) Operational Status are discovered.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Duplex status
item_prototype.description:
MIB: EtherLike-MIB The current mode of operation of the MAC entity. 'unknown' indicates that the current duplex mode could not be determined.
Management control of the duplex mode is accomplished through the MAU MIB. When an interface does not support autonegotiation, or when autonegotiation is not enabled, the duplex mode is controlled using ifMauDefaultType. When autonegotiation is supported and enabled, duplex mode is controlled using ifMauAutoNegAdvertisedBits. In either case, the currently operating duplex mode is reflected both in this object and in ifMauType.
Note that this object provides redundant information with ifMauType. Normally, redundant objects are discouraged. However, in this instance, it allows a management application to determine the duplex status of an interface without having to know every possible value of ifMauType. This was felt to be sufficiently valuable to justify the redundancy. Reference: [IEEE 802.3 Std.], 30.3.1.1.32,aDuplexStatus.

trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): In half-duplex mode
trigger_prototype.description: Please check autonegotiation settings and cabling

discovery_rule.name: Block devices discovery
discovery_rule.description: Block devices are discovered from UCD-DISKIO-MIB::diskIOTable (http://net-snmp.sourceforge.net/docs/mibs/ucdDiskIOMIB.html#diskIOTable)

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read rate
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-DISKIO-MIB The number of read accesses from this device since boot.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk utilization
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-DISKIO-MIB The 1 minute average load of disk (%)

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write rate
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-DISKIO-MIB The number of write accesses from this device since boot.

item_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Free inodes in %
item_prototype.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB If having problems collecting this item make sure access to UCD-SNMP-MIB is allowed.

parameters.parameter: return (100-value);

trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Running out of free inodes
trigger_prototype.description: It may become impossible to write to disk if there are no index nodes left. As symptoms, 'No space left on device' or 'Disk is full' errors may be seen even though free space is available.

trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Running out of free inodes
trigger_prototype.description: It may become impossible to write to disk if there are no index nodes left. As symptoms, 'No space left on device' or 'Disk is full' errors may be seen even though free space is available.

item_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Space utilization
item_prototype.description: Space utilization in % for {#FSNAME}

item_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Total space
item_prototype.description: MIB: HOST-RESOURCES-MIB The size of the storage represented by this entry, in units of hrStorageAllocationUnits. This object is writable to allow remote configuration of the size of the storage area in those cases where such an operation makes sense and is possible on the underlying system. For example, the amount of main storage allocated to a buffer pool might be modified or the amount of disk space allocated to virtual storage might be modified.

parameters.parameter: {#ALLOC_UNITS}

item_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Used space
item_prototype.description: MIB: HOST-RESOURCES-MIB The amount of the storage represented by this entry that is allocated, in units of hrStorageAllocationUnits.

parameters.parameter: {#ALLOC_UNITS}

trigger_prototype.expression: last(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}])>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and ((last(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.total[hrStorageSize.{#SNMPINDEX}])-last(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.used[hrStorageUsed.{#SNMPINDEX}]))<{$VFS.FS.FREE.MIN.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} or timeleft(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}],1h,100)<1d)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is critically low
trigger_prototype.description: Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}. Second condition should be one of the following: - The disk free space is less than {$VFS.FS.FREE.MIN.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}. - The disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

trigger_prototype.expression: last(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}])>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"} and ((last(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.total[hrStorageSize.{#SNMPINDEX}])-last(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.used[hrStorageUsed.{#SNMPINDEX}]))<{$VFS.FS.FREE.MIN.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"} or timeleft(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}],1h,100)<1d)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is low
trigger_prototype.description: Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}. Second condition should be one of the following: - The disk free space is less than {$VFS.FS.FREE.MIN.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}. - The disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

dependency.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is critically low
dependency.expression: last(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}])>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and ((last(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.total[hrStorageSize.{#SNMPINDEX}])-last(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.used[hrStorageUsed.{#SNMPINDEX}]))<{$VFS.FS.FREE.MIN.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} or timeleft(/Linux by SNMP/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}],1h,100)<1d)

macro.description: Load per CPU considered sustainable. Tune if needed.
Filter out loopbacks, nulls, docker veth links and docker0 bridge by default
This macro is used in block devices discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level
This macro is used in block devices discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level
The critical threshold of the filesystem utilization.
The warning threshold of the filesystem utilization.
This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level
This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level
This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level
This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level

trigger.expression: max(/Linux by SNMP/system.swap.pfree[snmp],5m)<{$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN} and last(/Linux by SNMP/system.swap.total[memTotalSwap.0])>0
trigger.name: High swap space usage
trigger.event_name: High swap space usage (less than {$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN}% free)
trigger.description: This trigger is ignored, if there is no swap configured.

dependency.name: Lack of available memory
dependency.expression: max(/Linux by SNMP/vm.memory.available[snmp],5m)<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} and last(/Linux by SNMP/vm.memory.total[memTotalReal.0])>0

trigger.expression: (last(/Linux by SNMP/system.hw.uptime[hrSystemUptime.0])>0 and last(/Linux by SNMP/system.hw.uptime[hrSystemUptime.0])<10m) or (last(/Linux by SNMP/system.hw.uptime[hrSystemUptime.0])=0 and last(/Linux by SNMP/system.net.uptime[sysUpTime.0])<10m)
trigger.name: Host has been restarted

trigger.expression: max(/Linux by SNMP/vm.memory.available[snmp],5m)<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} and last(/Linux by SNMP/vm.memory.total[memTotalReal.0])>0
trigger.name: Lack of available memory
Load average is too high
trigger.event_name: Load average is too high (per CPU load over {$LOAD_AVG_PER_CPU.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
trigger.description: Per CPU load average is too high. Your system may be slow to respond.
